Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jefft I was one too.... a newbie freshly diagnosed. Fear took over...I've got cancer. I'm screwed. I'm 59..starting doing the recommended screenings at 50 ...colonoscopy..siegmoid oscopy..blood tests .. everything fine til PSA went to 9.7 and biopsy scheduled. 5 out of 10 pins come back hot. I'm so screwed. Drank to level things out. Did a will. Did a little mid life crisis kinda shit. Worried too much. Didnt give modern science a chance. March 3 went in for the RP. It sucks yeah..but gotta get through it. Catheter is there..whatever. Best part is when you're actually under anesthetic and dont have to feel. But then...we have the post op appointment 7-10 days later with path report. I was mentally ready for salvage radiation. Then the good news. I'm clean... Found out today..TODAY! that i am clean from cancer. My doctors words.."couldnt have asked for a better result" I fucking cried. Had the Davinci S-i.. yes..the best machine on earth. Today I am joyous and want all you with surgery ahead to rest a little easier...dont go off the deep end. Let modern medical science do its thing. But keep clinging to the things that have suddenly become important to you. Tell your loved ones to get screened and tested. My prostate was three freaking times its normal size (will post bio later). Today I rejoice.. and you will too. Jeff that is GREAT news!!!!! woohoo!!

Posts.Title: Path report clear....my story..

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jefft Prostrate seems to always have most viewers ....we are a force to be reckoned with ! Trying to share the site with my 32 yr old nephew who is fighting brain tumors and getting proton therapy. He's had two surgeries and is chasing it around... He drives 360 miles a day from central washington to Seattles U of W Medical Center...believed to be one of the only two hospitals with proton. It it doesnt work he wont see his son go to high school. sending your son good thoughts!!

Posts.Title: Did they perform a junk transplant?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Brenden Was wondering if any of you have ever set off the alarm when you've gone through TSA's airport full-body security scanners while traveling by air. I just returned from a trip and set off the alarms in every airport full-body scanner I went through (i.e., Denver, Chicago, Dayton, Portland, Or.), which required that I be subjected to full body pat downs by TSA's agents each time. What's amazing is that over 60% of my body lit up and I have no idea why, nor does TSA. It's unlikely that it was caused by my radiation levels since I finished my rad treatments nearly 4 years. I'm Stage 4 (lots of bone mets) and the only drugs I'm on are Lupron (3-month injections) and Xgeva (monthly) Any ideas? yes.... and it would piss me off so damn bad it was not even funny. the fix???.... TSA precheck was the best money ive ever spent..... end of problem

Posts.Title: Had our first MD Anderson visit and surgery scheduled for April 1st

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Davis 928 Just got the phone call about post-op path you guys, and I'm telling myself it could be worse -- but I'm also discouraged to be honest. I (we) all hope that there is an end point where you are done and you can relax, that sounds like a rookie move in hindsight, doesn't it, but I guess I was looking for something to hang my hat on and be able to say yeah, this last week was all worth it. I got upgraded on histopath from a 3+3 to a Gleason 7 (4+3). There was also a small area on the margin which wasn't clean, apparently at the apex. Everything else like lymph nodes and vessicals was normal. The guy is saying we are talking microns here and he is not worried. He said there is a 90% chance I won't need radiation. It's not a concept I feel great about, it's just not a negative margin, so there's that. Davis. Hi Davis that is the glass 90% full They way i see it you are here to whine about it.... and in my opinion that's GREAT! Hang in there.

Posts.Title: Liftoff!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by living with Pca My husband started chemo and is on his 5 th cycle. Upon every appointment there has been a gift from our daughter. She has a bag with treats- lemon drops for bad taste- flavor water- and other treats. Along with a card with encouraging words about strength and fighting this cancer. Our grand daughter adds a color picture to bring him joy. I think all the staff is looking forward to the bags of gifts as much as Steve is. Maybe this can start something from all you caregivers and familys out there It is the things people say and do that heals us as much or more than medical science. That is just so darn sweet of her!! Great idea too.... Tell your daughter shes doing a great job with this gift......

Posts.Title: Daughters gift

Posts.Content: hi Shaney im sorry you find yourself here but its a good place to ask questions. I think the mods may move your thread to worried about cancer so you will get more views on your spacific issues... as just some general support...my first suggestion is to stay off of google looking for "the answers" All it will get you is a huge dose of crazy..... Relax and just wait and see what happens with the results.... at this point it could be anything and not just the jump to cancer. Hang in there.... we all understand the scared to death thing. (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Prostate cancer breakthrough as test flags up the most aggressive form of the disease Protein identified which plays crucial role in the rapid growth of tumours Discovery raises hopes of test that deliver an early accurate diagnosis Could lead to more targeted treatment for those with worst cancers http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/ar...m-disease.html

Posts.Content: by all means make your plans. Plan for the best and prepare for the worst. Check with your doctor too. look into cancellation policies very carefully. Ask very spacific question about refundable tickets due to illness. If it would be helpful, ask for seats close to the toilet. Also look into travel insurance just in case.

Posts.Title: What was your strategy about telling your employer, and how did it work out for you?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lukasnyc Hi My fathers PSA from last year went from 4.5 to 5.2 . He had his 12 point biopsy done and today came back positive for pc. I dont know yet his number for sure but I believe he mentioned 7. His doctor send him for bone and lymph node scan. He is 64 years young. I'm also upset because previous doctor he went to when he was 4.5 told him not to worry and didn't order any fallow up tests. He never had any symptoms. Im just worried and scared. We are in NYC and I know that are few great surgeons that you guys recommend. Any help, advice will be highly appreciated. Im 37 now and I guess I have to make an appointment and get myself check too - is that a good idea ? im sorry to hear about your father. I hope everything works out.

Posts.Content: Hey bunnabrock Im glad you made the move to MDA and are getting the care your husband needs. You both hang in there and stay healthy..... Good luck with with your journey. There are a lot of people here who can help answer your questions. Edit..was also answering your question in general when it was combined..... hey bunnabrock I don't remember what the testosterone numbers were with my husband. He was also on the very low level of normal but it was not associated with cancer. Just my input here from personal experience.... In my opinion the injections are better then the patch or gel treatments. If they do put him on topical testosterone..... be very careful of transfer to you.

I dont know yet his number for sure but I believe he mentioned 7. His doctor send him for bone and lymph node scan. He is 64 years young. I'm also upset because previous doctor he went to when he was 4.5 told him not to worry and didn't order any fallow up tests. He never had any symptoms. Im just worried and scared. We are in NYC and I know that are few great surgeons that you guys recommend. Any help, advice will be highly appreciated. Im 37 now and I guess I have to make an appointment and get myself check too - is that a good idea ? im sorry to hear about your father. I hope everything works out.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jnight72 Prato, I'm not sure if it really is actually an infection as I am not sure I have ever had one before. Wondering if it is the new reality. It seems to be a little inconsistent, which is why I thought infection. Maybe I should try the cranberry juice or a cranberry supplement. Just wanted to see if it was going on with others. Thanks for the input. hey there... if you think you have a UTI.... go in and have them check your pee. If not treated it will move from your bladder to your kidneys...and then you are in a real world of hurt. The longer you wait the harder it is to treat. Its painful to pee... the pee will go from coldly to bloody and you will experience incontinence.

Posts.Title: Urinary tract infections??

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jnight72 Never been painful, just a feeling of it being empty or having to go again. I just thought those could be symptoms. Have my one year follow up coming soon. Will mention it. Thanks! ok..i know the feeling you are talking about. I had the same feeling after my hysterectomy.... there was just more room and a new feeling to adjust to. Can you send a message to your doc telling him about it? Ive learned that anything "different" they always want to know about..... and.... YAY 1 year out!!!!! woohoo.

Posts.Title: Urinary tract infections??

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WifeinWorry Anyone have any good experience with medicinal oils, not any specific ones, just any oils to help rid cancer or suppress it? Alright... gonna weigh in here. Sanke oil is snake oil.....No oil is going to help rid you of cancer. Look at it this way..... if there was some magic oil that would kill cancer or suppress it.... every drug manufacture would be all over it and selling it to you. But...if it makes you feel good or better taking the oil..... woohoo great take all you want. Just dont make the mistake thinking its going to cure you.

Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WifeinWorry Visit with Moffitt, time for chemo....aggressive cancer, aggressive treatments...chemo starts Friday for my husband. They are starting him on Docetaxel. This is all new for us, what to expect? Side effects, quality of life for the next 8 sessions? He's getting one hour, once every three weeks for about 8 sessions I believe. Anyone out there that took Docetaxel, how did it work for you? Im hangin in there. It gets tough when you find out there's more chemicals smothering his body, and hoping it works and there's some sort of remission... I am not sure with the Docetaxel... they are all different. Did they give you a list of things to watch for? I also know its very hard for you having to watch on the sidelines while this is happening. Hang in there and stay strong. My fingers are crossed for you both.
Posts.Signature: I must not fear. Fear is the mind-killer. Fear is the little-death that brings total obliteration. I will face my fear. I will permit it to pass over me and through me. And when it has gone past I will turn the inner eye to see its path. Where the fear has gone there will be nothing. Only I will remain.
Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by azgreywolf Jebstart, I was left with one nerve, badly damaged. 150mg of Viagra gave a little size, but still too droopy to even try to use. Trimix only got me a semi, again not adequate for penetration. A vacuum pump with 3 rings got me fully up, but much of the blood pushed back out anyway on insertion and I'd be in but floppy. I've had one orgasm via intercourse in 3.5 years. The implant is my last great hope. If you're only 10 months out and getting a semi, give it some time. I've heard surgeons won't do an implant till 24 months post-op at the earliest. Did you try ... muse? it is not an oral drug and works differently then the family of drugs like viagra and cialis. It is a penile suppository that you must keep in the refrigerator. I do not know if this would work for you, but it is at least something else to give a try before and implant.
